item.title: UFO (British TV series)
item.description:
UFO (British TV series) ðŸ”—

A British science fiction television series that aired from 1970 to 1971, focusing on Earth’s defense against an alien invasion in the then-future of 1980.

Premise ðŸ”—

In 1980, Earth is under threat from aliens from a dying planet who are abducting humans for their organs. SHADO (Supreme Headquarters Alien Defence Organisation), a secret international military agency operating under the guise of a movie studio, is formed to defend Earth. SHADO utilizes advanced technology, including a space intruder detection satellite (SID), lunar interceptors, a submarine/aircraft called Skydiver, and ground-based SHADO Mobiles. The aliens are humanoid, requiring a green oxygenated liquid and special contact lenses. Their UFOs can travel faster than light but have limited time in Earth’s atmosphere.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

The series features a large ensemble cast with frequent changes. Ed Bishop as Commander Ed Straker is the only actor to appear in every episode.

Main characters ðŸ”—

  • Commander Edward Straker (Ed Bishop): The head of SHADO, posing as the head of Harlington-Straker Film Studios.
  • Colonel Paul Foster (Michael Billington): A former test pilot recruited into SHADO.
  • Lieutenant Gay Ellis (Gabrielle Drake): Moonbase commander.
  • Colonel Alec Freeman (George Sewell): SHADO’s second-in-command.
  • General James Henderson (Grant Taylor): Straker’s superior and president of the International Astrophysical Commission.
  • Colonel Virginia Lake (Wanda Ventham): A SHADO operative who later becomes first officer.
  • Captain Peter Carlin (Peter Gordeno): First commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Nina Barry (Dolores Mantez): Moonbase operative.
  • Captain Lew Waterman (Gary Myers): Second commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Keith Ford (Keith Alexander): Communications officer.
  • Lieutenant Ayshea Johnson (Ayshea Brough): SHADO headquarters officer.
  • Doctor Douglas Jackson (Vladek Sheybal): SHADO psychiatrist and science officer.
  • Lieutenant Joan Harrington (Antonia Ellis): Moonbase operative.
  • Miss Ealand (Norma Ronald): Straker’s secretary.
  • Lieutenant Mark Bradley (Harry Baird): Interceptor pilot.

Minor characters ðŸ”—

Shakira Baksh (later Michael Caine’s wife) played Joanna, a Moonbase operative. Steven Berkoff played Interceptor pilot Steve Minto, and Georgina Moon played Lieutenant Sylvia Howell.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The 26 episodes were broadcast in a non-chronological order by ITV. The list provides the original ATV (Midlands) broadcast order, along with director, writer, original air date, and production code. Episode titles include “Identified,” “Exposed,” “The Cat with Ten Lives,” “Conflict,” “A Question of Priorities,” and “The Long Sleep.”

Alternative viewing orders ðŸ”—

Different viewing orders exist, including production order, ATV broadcast order, and recommended orders by UFO Series, Fanderson, and ITC. A table compares these different orders.

Production ðŸ”—

Lew Grade approached Gerry Anderson to create a live-action TV series, resulting in UFO. The series was influenced by UFO sightings and Christiaan Barnard’s transplant operations. Sylvia Anderson designed the costumes, including the purple wigs for female Moonbase staff. The Harlington-Straker Studio was the actual studio where the series was filmed.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming began in April 1969 at MGM-British Studios, then moved to Pinewood Studios in June 1970. George Sewell and Gabrielle Drake left after the studio change. Harry Baird and Peter Gordeno also left the series.

Costumes ðŸ”—

Female Moonbase personnel wore purple wigs, silver catsuits, and heavy eye makeup for a futuristic look. Ed Bishop initially bleached his hair, then wore a white wig. Other male characters also wore wigs. Only two alien suits were made.

Special effects ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings supervised the special effects, using techniques like double-walled visors and underwater effects.

Vehicle design ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings and Mike Trim designed the vehicles. The gull-winged cars were originally built for DoppelgÃ¤nger. The blue SHADO Jeeps were built on Mini Moke chassis. Few original props and miniatures have survived.

Broadcast ðŸ”—

Broadcasters were unsure if UFO was for adults or children. In the UK, episodes were shown in the late afternoon and Saturday mornings.

Reception ðŸ”—

Reviews of UFO are mixed. Some praise the visuals, music, and costumes, while others criticize the writing and pacing. Some reviews note the series’ mix of adult themes and science fiction elements.

Aborted second series ðŸ”—

ITC commissioned a second series, UFO 2, set entirely on the Moon. However, when ratings dropped, ITC cancelled the plans. Gerry Anderson then created Space: 1999 from the pre-production work.

Merchandise ðŸ”—

The series generated a range of toys, including Dinky die-cast vehicles.

Compilation films ðŸ”—

Several episodes were compiled into films, including Invasion: UFO. Italian producers also created compilation films with mixed reviews.

Home media ðŸ”—

Channel 5 and ITC released VHS collections. The complete series was released on DVD in 2002.

Proposed feature film ðŸ”—

In 2009, a feature film adaptation was announced, but it did not enter production.

In other media ðŸ”—

Stories set in the UFO universe have appeared in novels, comics, and video games. Julian Gollop cited UFO as an influence for UFO: Enemy Unknown. Yoshiyuki Sadamoto drew inspiration from UFO for character designs in Neon Genesis Evangelion.

Translations ðŸ”—

The series has been translated into French, German, Japanese, Italian, Spanish, and Brazilian Portuguese.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(British_TV_series)

item.title: Fictional Creatures in a Fictional Universe
item.description:
Fictional Creatures in a Fictional Universe ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article provides a comprehensive list of fictional creatures and aliens from the Doctor Who universe, a long-running BBC science fiction television series. It notes the show’s initial run from 1963 to 1989, its revival in 2005, and the central character, the Doctor, an extraterrestrial who travels through time and space in the TARDIS. The list excludes specific characters and focuses on alien races and fictional creatures, including those appearing in spin-off series like The Sarah Jane Adventures, Torchwood, and Class, but excludes antagonists original to those series.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “A.”

Abzorbaloff ðŸ”—

The Abzorbaloff is an alien creature from the planet Clom, known for absorbing living beings into its body through touch. It appeared in the episode “Love & Monsters” (2006). In this episode, an Abzorbalovian disguised as “Victor Kennedy” infiltrated a group called L.I.N.D.A. to gain knowledge from the Doctor. The Abzorbaloff was ultimately defeated when Elton Pope broke its cane, causing the Earth to absorb it. The creature was created by William Grantham, a nine-year-old who won a Blue Peter contest. Comedian Peter Kay portrayed the Abzorbaloff on-screen. A short sequel, “The Genuine Article,” features the Abzorbaloff’s father seeking revenge, directed and animated by Grantham.

Adipose ðŸ”—

The Adipose are aliens composed of living fat, featured in the episode “Partners in Crime” (2008). Originating from the lost breeding world Adipose 3, they rely on a drug formulated by “Miss Foster” to convert human fat into Adipose children through parthenogenesis. This process, if accelerated, can be fatal to the host. The Adipose abandoned Foster to hide their illegal activities. In an alternate timeline in “Turn Left” (2008), the Adipose incident in America resulted in over 60 million deaths. The Adipose were inspired by a plush toy owned by writer Russell T Davies.

Aggedor ðŸ”—

Aggedor is the Sacred Royal Beast of the planet Peladon, first appearing in The Curse of Peladon (1972). The creature is a large, hairy beast with a single horn, hunted to near extinction. In the story, Peladon’s High Priest, Hepesh, used a captured Aggedor to generate superstition and prevent Peladon from joining the Galactic Federation. Actor Nick Hobbs portrayed Aggedor in both The Curse of Peladon and The Monster of Peladon (1974). The audio story The Bride of Peladon reveals Aggedor had a child, which later gave birth to many baby Aggedors.

Axons ðŸ”—

The Axons are golden-skinned humanoids who attempt to take over Earth by distributing Axonite, pieces of the single creature Axos, in The Claws of Axos (1971). They pose as a friendly family but can shapeshift into monstrous forms. The Axons are later trapped in a time loop alongside Axos. Actors Bernard Holley, Patricia Gordino, John Hicks, and Debbie Lee London portrayed the Axons. The Axons reappeared in the 2010 comic strip “The Golden Ones,” where they attempted to free Axos and rampage across Tokyo until defeated by the Eleventh Doctor.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “B.”

Bandril ðŸ”—

The Bandrils are a reptilian species encountered in the serial Timelash (1985). A villain known as the Borad seeks to start a war between them and the people of Karfel. The Sixth Doctor is able to thwart the plot. Actor Martin Gower portrayed the Bandril Ambassador.

Boneless ðŸ”—

The Boneless are creatures from a two-dimensional universe, seen in “Flatline” (2014). They harness energy from the TARDIS to infiltrate the Doctor’s universe. Clara Oswald and Rigsy trick the Boneless into restoring the TARDIS, allowing the Doctor to send them back to their home dimension. The Boneless later appeared in the comic story The Fourth Wall, where they use comic books to trap readers until the Twelfth Doctor defeats them.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “C.”

Carrionite ðŸ”—

The Carrionites are creatures from “The Dark Times,” who fought against the Time Lords. They appear in “The Shakespeare Code” (2007). Three Carrionites, Bloodtide, Doomfinger, and Lilith, attempt to release their species from a prison using the power of words and witchcraft, manipulating William Shakespeare. The Tenth Doctor and Shakespeare reverse the process, trapping the Carrionites back into their prison. They reappeared in the audio drama The Carrionite Curse, facing the Sixth Doctor.

Catkind ðŸ”—

The Catkind are felines evolved into humanoids, first seen in “New Earth” (2006). They have hair-covered bodies, feline facial features, and retractable claws. In “New Earth,” the Sisters of Plenitude, a group of Catkind, run a hospital where they test on human subjects. The Tenth Doctor develops a cure, and the Sisters are arrested. In “Gridlock” (2007), a Cat Person, Thomas Kincade Brannigan, has a human wife and kittens. Novice Hame, a surviving Sister of Plentitude, aids the Tenth Doctor. Actress Anna Hope portrayed Hame. A short scene, “The Secret of Novice Hame,” depicts Hame on her deathbed.

Chameleons ðŸ”—

Chameleons are aliens with no features who can take on the appearance of individual humans, seen in The Faceless Ones (1967). They lost their identities in an explosion and kidnap humans to adopt their identities. The Second Doctor convinces them to seek another solution. The Chameleons later re-appeared in the spin-off book Short Trips and Side Steps, where they infiltrate the planet Krennos until the Sixth Doctor stops them.

Cheetah People ðŸ”—

Cheetah People are feline humanoids resembling cheetahs who enjoy hunting humans, encountered in Survival (1989). They were once humanoids who mutated after bonding with cat-like creatures known as Kitlings. The Master, stranded on their planet, attempts to use them to escape. The Seventh Doctor stops the Master, leaving him stranded. Writer Rona Munro was disappointed with the final version of the Cheetah People.

Chronovores ðŸ”—

Chronovores are glowing white creatures that live outside time, one of whom, Kronos, is encountered in The Time Monster (1972). The Master attempts to use Kronos, but the Third Doctor thwarts his plans. The Chronovores re-appeared in the book The Quantum Archangel, where Kronos sought revenge against the Master and sacrificed itself to stop the Chronovores from feeding on Earth.

Chuldur ðŸ”—

The Chuldur are a race of shape shifting bird-like aliens who appeared in the Fifteenth Doctor story “Rogue” (2024). The Chuldur appeared in 1813, where they infiltrated a ball in order to “cosplay” as those from the nineteenth century. The Fifteenth Doctor is able to trap the Chuldur within a sealing device, which banished them to another dimension, but at the sacrifice of Rogue, a bounty hunter the Doctor had fallen in love with.

Cryons ðŸ”—

Cryons are an all-female species of alien first seen in Attack of the Cybermen (1985). They cannot exist at temperatures above zero degrees. The Cryons lived on Telos until the Cybermen took control, and allied with the mercenary Lytton to defeat them. The Cryons were later destroyed by an attack by the Cybermen. Director Matthew Robinson elected to make the Cryons an all-female race.

Cyberman ðŸ”—

The Cybermen are humanoids originating on Earth’s twin planet Mondas, first seen in The Tenth Planet (1966). They replace organic body parts with artificial ones, becoming coldly logical. The Cyberman concept was created by Dr. Kit Pedler and Gerry Davis in 1966. The Cybermen were portrayed by tall actors. In the two-part story “Rise of the Cybermen” and “The Age of Steel” (2006), the Cybermen originate on a parallel-universe version of Earth, created by John Lumic. The Cybermen have several variants, such as the Cybermat and the Cybershades.

D ðŸ”—

This section lists alien creatures whose names begin with the letter “D.”

DÃ¦mon ðŸ”—

A race of humanoids from the planet DÃ¦mos, seen in The DÃ¦mons (1971). They resemble demons and have great power. The Master attempts to obtain the power of a DÃ¦mon named Azal, but Jo Grant sacrifices herself, confusing Azal and reversing his powers, killing him. Another DÃ¦mon later appeared in the unofficial 2004 BBV film DÃ¦mos Rising, and the spin-off novel Child of Time.

Dalek ðŸ”—

The

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_universe_creatures_and_aliens

item.title: Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise
item.description:
Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise ðŸ”—

This article provides a comprehensive list of alien races featured in the Star Trek franchise, spanning from the original series to the latest installments. It emphasizes the significance of these alien encounters as a core element of the Star Trek narrative.

Key ðŸ”—

This section provides a key to the abbreviations used throughout the list to indicate the specific Star Trek media (TV series, films) in which each alien race appears. It includes the title, date, and medium for each abbreviation.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

  • Aenar: A sub-species of Andorians from the planet Andoria, characterized by their light blue/white skin, near-blindness, and telepathic abilities. They are generally pacifistic. Key figures include Hemmer from Strange New Worlds and Talla, Shran’s daughter.
  • Andorian: A blue-skinned, antenna-bearing humanoid species from Andoria. They are depicted as a warrior race and were founding members of the United Federation of Planets.
  • Angosian: A species known for genetically and chemically engineering soldiers for the Tarsian Wars. These “super soldiers” were later confined to a penal settlement.
  • Antedean: An ichthyohumanoid species from Antede III that resembles fish and has a strong aversion to space travel.
  • Arcadian: A member of the United Federation of Planets with a representative on the Federation Council. They have large, round heads and distinctive hairstyles.
  • Arcturian: A species known for their clones, which have a melted skin appearance. They hail from the densely populated world Arcturus.
  • Axanar: The first extraterrestrial race befriended by Earth people aboard the NX-01 Enterprise. Captain Garth of Izar achieved a great victory on behalf of the Federation at the Battle of Axanar.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

  • Bajoran: A humanoid species from the planet Bajor, characterized by nose ridges and deep spirituality. They worship The Prophets and were occupied by the Cardassians. Key locations include Bajor.
  • Ba’ku: A technologically advanced humanoid civilization that chose to abandon technology and live a simple life on an isolated planet with metaphasic radiation. Their aging process is significantly slowed. Key locations include The Briar Patch.
  • Benzite: A humanoid race from the planet Benzar, a member of the United Federation of Planets. They are known for their resistance to poisons and ability to digest almost any organic compound.
  • Betazoid: A telepathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed, a member of the United Federation of Planets. Deanna Troi is a prominent half-Betazoid character.
  • Bolian: Humanoids with blue skin and a ridge running from the back of their heads to their noses. They are active members of the Federation and known for crystal steel and the Bank of Bolius.
  • Borg: A pseudo-species of cybernetically enhanced individuals forming a collective consciousness. They assimilate other species to achieve perfection.
  • Breen: A mysterious race who joined the Dominion during the Dominion War.
  • Brikar: A large, rock-like species. Rok-Tahk from Star Trek: Prodigy is a notable example.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

  • Cardassian: A species with ridges along their foreheads and necks, known for their military dictatorship and conflict with the United Federation of Planets. Key figures include Garak and Gul Dukat. Their homeworld is Cardassia Prime.
  • Chameloid: A race of shapeshifters. Martia is a notable example encountered by Kirk and McCoy.
  • Changeling: A race of fluid shapeshifters who founded the Dominion. Odo is a prominent Changeling character.

D ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “D.”

  • Douwd: Immortal energy beings with vast powers. Only one is known to exist, who committed xenocide against the Husnock.
  • Deltan: A humanoid species from the planet Delta IV, known for their strong sexual attraction. They take a vow of chastity upon joining Starfleet. Ilia and Melle are notable Deltans.

E ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “E.”

  • Edosian: A race of sentient tripedal beings. Lieutenant Arex was introduced in Star Trek: The Animated Series.
  • El-Aurian: A humanoid race known as “Listeners,” with long lifespans and a patient, wise demeanor. Their homeworld, El-Auria, was destroyed by the Borg. Guinan is a notable El-Aurian.

F ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “F.”

  • Ferengi: A species known for their focus on profit and the Rules of Acquisition. Quark is a notable Ferengi character. Their homeworld is Ferenginar.

G ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “G.”

  • Gorn: A violent, lizard-like species known for kidnapping people to serve as incubators for their eggs.

H ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “H.”

  • Hirogen: A violent Delta Quadrant species whose culture is based on hunting other sentient species.
  • Horta: Silicon-based life forms that eat rock on the planet Janus VI.

I ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “I.”

  • Illyrian: A species that practices genetic augmentation to adapt to various environments.

J ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “J.”

  • Jem’Hadar: Genetically engineered shock troops of the Dominion, bred for strength and loyalty to the Founders.

K ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “K.”

  • Kazon: A species introduced in Star Trek: Voyager. They are a nomadic species.
  • Kelpien: A species from the planet Kaminar, suppressed by the Ba’ul for generations. Commander Saru is a notable Kelpien.
  • Klingon: A warrior race with a strict honor code and ridged foreheads. Their homeworld is Kronos.
  • Kzinti: Feline warriors who had four wars with humanity.

L ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “L.”

  • Lanthanite: A long-lived species that has been secretly present on Earth since the 22nd century. Chief Engineer Pelia is a notable Lanthanite.

O ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “O.”

  • Ocampa: A humanoid species from the Delta Quadrant with a history of great mental feats.
  • Organian: Incorporeal energy creatures who render weapons inoperable to prevent conflict.
  • Orion: A green-skinned, humanoid species.

P ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “P.”

  • Pakled: A species that obtains technology from other races, often through trickery.

Q ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “Q.”

  • Q: Immortal, omnipotent beings who belong to the Q Continuum. One Q is particularly interested in humanity.

R ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “R.”

  • Romulan: A violent, treacherous offshoot of the Vulcans who rule the Romulan Empire. Their homeworld is Romulus.
  • Reman: A humanoid caste related to the Romulans, forced to live as enslaved under the Romulans and work in the dilithium mines on Remus.

S ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “S.”

  • Son’a: Former members of the Ba’ku who were exiled for embracing technology.
  • Species 8472: A powerful species from fluidic space that surpasses the Borg in combat prowess.

T ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “T.”

  • Talaxian: A species from the Delta Quadrant. Neelix is a notable Talaxian character.
  • Talosian: A race with the power of illusions from Talos IV.
  • Tellarite: A species known for their love of arguing and blunt speech. Their homeworld is Tellar Prime.
  • Tholian: A xenophobic, non-humanoid hermaphroditic species with a propensity for precision.
  • Tribble: A small, harmless species noted for their rapid reproduction.
  • Trill: A humanoid species where a small minority are joined with a long-lived symbiont. Jadzia Dax and Ezri Dax are notable Trill characters.

V ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “V.”

  • Vidiian: A species encountered in the Delta Quadrant

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Star_Trek_aliens

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and large, black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoids with grey skin, elongated bodies, small chests, and a lack of muscular definition. They are said to lack external human body parts like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their most striking feature is their disproportionately large heads with no hair and large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance ðŸ”—

This subsection further elaborates on the physical appearance of Grey aliens. They are generally depicted as lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. The most prominent feature is their large, black, almond-shaped eyes, often described as lacking eye whites. They are also frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the origin of the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association began with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and determined that the aliens’ home was Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. It notes that descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate alien encounter claims, citing H.G. Wells’ descriptions of future humans in “The Man of the Year Million” (1893) and the Eloi in “The Time Machine” (1895).

Origins ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien concept. H.G. Wells’ depictions of future humans and the Eloi are mentioned as early examples of beings with Grey-like characteristics. Aleister Crowley’s 1917 encounter with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, described as similar to a modern Grey, is also discussed. Gustav Sandgren’s 1933 science fiction novel, Den okÃ¤nda faran (The Unknown Danger), which describes a race of extraterrestrials with grey skin, bald heads, and large eyes, is identified as a key influence on the modern image of Grey aliens.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. The Hills claimed that in 1961, they were abducted by grayish-skinned humanoid beings and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer’s 1990 article suggests that Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which featured an alien with large eyes. Carl Sagan echoed these suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses how Grey aliens became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hill’s encounter. Journalist C.D.B. Bryan notes that 73% of reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. The section also mentions the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, and claims that individuals saw the U.S. military handling child-sized beings with oversized heads and slanted eyes. Whitley Strieber’s 1987 book Communion, which described his alleged encounters with Greys, is also discussed. Jimmy Guieu’s 1988 interview on TF1’s Ciel, mon mardi! introduced the term “the little greys” to the French public.

The section further notes that Greys have become the subject of many conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of a government disinformation campaign or a product of mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli’s 1995 film Alien Autopsy, which claimed to depict the autopsy of a “real” Grey, is also mentioned.

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section examines various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

This subsection analyzes the role of Greys in alien abduction claims. It notes that Greys make up a significant percentage of reported alien encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focus of abduction claims, with abductees reporting that the Greys stare into their eyes during mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses Frederick V. Malmstrom’s “Mother Hypothesis,” which suggests that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom argues that the face of a Grey can be reconstructed through transformation of a mother’s face based on early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

This subsection briefly mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section explores the depiction of Grey aliens in popular culture. It notes that Greys have become a common way to depict extraterrestrials in fiction, supplanting the “little green men” archetype. Examples include Ultraman (1966), Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. The section also mentions the increasing association of Greys with conspiracy theories in the 1990s, citing The X-Files as a prominent example. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The films Paul (2011) and Dark Skies (2013) are also mentioned, as well as the TV series Resident Alien (2021) and the game Greyhill Incident (2023).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_aliens

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulians, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin, lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition, and having disproportionately short legs. A key feature is their large heads relative to their bodies, devoid of hair, with small orifices for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their eyes are large, opaque, black, and almond-shaped. They are often described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

The connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system stems from Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and identified the stars as Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype.

Origins ðŸ”—

Descriptions of beings resembling Grey aliens predate reported encounters. H.G. Wells described future humans with similar features in his 1893 article “The Man of the Year Million” and his 1895 novel The Time Machine. In 1917, Aleister Crowley described an entity named Lam with a similar appearance. In 1933, Swedish novelist Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described aliens with grey clothes, bald heads, and large eyes in his science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 brought the Grey alien archetype to public attention in 1965. The Hills claimed they were abducted by grey-skinned humanoids and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which aired shortly before Barney’s first hypnotic session. Carl Sagan also suggested Invaders from Mars as a potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

Following the Hill’s encounter, Greys became a central figure in ufology and extraterrestrial folklore, particularly in the United States, where they account for 73% of reported alien encounters. The alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, was later linked to Greys. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published Communion, a book detailing his alleged encounters with Greys, which became a bestseller and was adapted into a film. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu introduced the term “les Petits-Gris” (little greys) to French audiences.

Greys have become the subject of conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of government disinformation campaigns or mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage of an autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from Roswell, but later admitted it was a “reconstruction.”

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

Greys are frequently associated with alien abduction claims, accounting for a significant percentage of reported encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focal point, with claims of inducing hallucinogenic states or emotions through staring.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

Neurologist Steven Novella suggests that Grey aliens are a product of the human imagination, with their features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

Frederick V. Malmstrom proposes that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development, reconstructing the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

Biologist Jack Cohen argues that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

The interdimensional, cryptoterrestrial, and time-traveler hypotheses offer alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of these alleged beings.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section highlights the presence of Grey aliens in various forms of media.

Grey aliens have become a common depiction of extraterrestrials in fiction, replacing the earlier “little green men.” They have appeared in films and television shows such as Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, and Stargate. During the 1990s, plotlines linking Greys to conspiracy theories became prevalent, as seen in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The film Paul features a Grey alien who attributes the Greys’ presence in pop culture to government manipulation. The film Dark Skies features child abduction by Greys. Greys also appear in the TV series Resident Alien and the game Greyhill Incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_alien

item.title: Alien
item.description:
Alien ðŸ”—

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979â€“present

Premise ðŸ”—

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background ðŸ”—

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, MÅ“bius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

Films ðŸ”—

This section lists the Alien films, including the original series, Alien vs. Predator films, and Prometheus films. It includes the U.S. release date, director, screenwriter(s), story by, and producer(s) for each film.

Original series ðŸ”—

  • Alien (1979): Directed by Ridley Scott, starring Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley. The crew of the Nostromo encounters a deadly alien creature.
  • Aliens (1986): Directed by James Cameron, Ripley returns to LV-426 with a squad of marines to investigate a lost colony.
  • Alien 3 (1992): Directed by David Fincher, Ripley crash-lands on a prison planet and faces a new alien threat.
  • Alien Resurrection (1997): Directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, Ripley is cloned 200 years after her death, and the military attempts to exploit the Aliens.

Crossover series ðŸ”—

  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, a group of explorers discovers an ancient pyramid in Antarctica, where they become caught in a battle between Aliens and Predators.
  • Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem (2007): Directed by Greg & Colin Strause, the Predalien hybrid from the previous film causes a Predator ship to crash in Gunnison, Colorado, leading to a battle between Aliens and a Predator.

Prequel series ðŸ”—

  • Prometheus (2012): Directed by Ridley Scott, scientists Elizabeth Shaw and Charlie Holloway discover a star map and travel to LV-223, where they encounter the Engineers.
  • Alien: Covenant (2017): Directed by Ridley Scott, the crew of the Covenant traces a transmission to an Engineer homeworld, where they encounter David 8 and a new breed of Alien.

Spin-off film ðŸ”—

  • Alien: Romulus (2024): Directed by Fede Ãlvarez, set between Alien and Aliens.

Future ðŸ”—

Discusses potential future installments in the Alien franchise, including a cancelled Alien 5 project by Neill Blomkamp and ongoing development of new films.

Short films ðŸ”—

This section lists the Alien short films, including the U.S. release date, director(s), screenwriter(s), and producer(s) for each film.

Television and web series ðŸ”—

This section lists the television and web series in the Alien franchise, including the season, episodes, originally released dates, network, showrunner(s), and status for each series.

  • Alien: Isolation â€“ The Digital Series (2019): A seven-episode animated adaptation of the video game Alien: Isolation.
  • Alien: Earth (2025): A new TV series project based on the franchise, set on Earth in the near future.

Cast and crew ðŸ”—

This section lists the principal cast and additional crew members involved in the Alien franchise.

Principal cast ðŸ”—

Lists actors and the characters they portrayed in the films, web series, television series, and audio dramas. Key actors include Sigourney Weaver as Ellen Ripley, Ian Holm as Ash, Lance Henriksen as Bishop II Michael Bishop Weyland, Carrie Henn as Rebecca “Newt” Jorden, Michael Biehn as Dwayne Hicks, Noomi Rapace as Elizabeth M. Shaw, and Michael Fassbender as David 8.

Additional crew ðŸ”—

Lists the composers, cinematographers, editors, production companies, and distributors for each Alien film.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section discusses the box office performance, critical and public response, and accolades received by the Alien films.

Box office performance ðŸ”—

Provides a table of the box office revenue for each Alien film, including North America, foreign, and worldwide totals, as well as the budget for each film.

Critical and public response ðŸ”—

Provides a table of the critical and public response to each Alien film, including Rotten Tomatoes scores, Metacritic scores, and CinemaScore grades.

Accolades ðŸ”—

Lists the Academy Award nominations for Alien films.

Alien Day ðŸ”—

Discusses “Alien Day,” the fan celebration day for the Alien franchise on April 26.

Alien: The Play ðŸ”—

Discusses the North Bergen High School’s adaptation of Alien entitled Alien: The Play, which was widely praised.

In academia ðŸ”—

Discusses the Bishop character as a high-profile android character conforming to Isaac Asimov’s Three Laws of Robotics.

Music ðŸ”—

Lists the soundtracks for Alien films, including the U.S. release date, length, composer(s), and label for each soundtrack.

Home media ðŸ”—

Discusses the various home media releases of the Alien films, including VHS, Laserdisc, DVD, and Blu-ray.

Other media ðŸ”—

This section discusses spin-offs in other media, including crossovers with the Predator franchise.

Print media ðŸ”—

Discusses Alien print media, including novelizations of the films, original content that expand upon the fictional universe, comics, and companion books.

Novels ðŸ”—

Lists several novelizations of each of the six films and some comic books as well as original canonical novels based on the franchise have been released.

Comic books ðŸ”—

Discusses the numerous limited series set in the Alien universe, as well as non-canonical crossover appearances of the Alien.

Picture books ðŸ”—

Discusses Jonesy: Nine Lives on the Nostromo, a 2018 picture book that retells the plot of Alien (1979) from the perspective of Jones, the ship’s cat from the film.

Video games ðŸ”—

Discusses the numerous video games released over the years, spanning a variety of genres.

Merchandising ðŸ”—

Discusses the merchandise manufactured and marketed to a wide range of age groups.

Theme park attractions ðŸ”—

Discusses the Alien-themed attraction at the Genting SkyWorlds Theme Park in Malaysia and The Great Movie Ride at Disney’s Hollywood Studios.

Alien vs. Predator franchise ðŸ”—

Discusses the Alien vs. Predator franchise, inspired by the Dark Horse Comics series.

The Predator (2018) ðŸ”—

Discusses the alternate endings of Shane Black’s The Predator (2018), which featured Ellen Ripley and Rebecca “Newt” Jorden.

See also ðŸ”—

Lists related topics, including space science fiction franchises, films featuring extraterrestrials, and monster movies.

item.title: List of humanoid aliens
item.description:
List of Humanoid Aliens ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry is a compilation of fictional extraterrestrial humanoid characters from various media. It emphasizes that these aliens possess human-like traits such as upright posture, bipedalism, opposable thumbs, and facial features. The list is organized by medium: Animation, Comics, Film, Literature, Television, and Video Games. Each entry includes the character’s name, origin (the work in which they appear), and brief notes about their role or characteristics. The article is flagged as needing additional citations for verification and may not be complete.

Animation ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in animated works. Key characters include:

  • The Great Gazoo (The Flintstones): A tiny alien exiled to Earth who can only be seen by Fred, Barney, children, and animals.
  • Cure Princess/Hime Shirayuki (HappinessCharge PreCure!): A princess from the Blue Sky Kingdom.
  • Mikitaka Hazekura (JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure): An alien who appears as a teenage boy with pointed ears.
  • Interplanet Janet (Schoolhouse Rock): A cyborg girl from another galaxy.
  • Jet Propulsion (Ready Jet Go!): An alien from Bortron 7 studying Earth.
  • Cure Milky/Lala Hagoromo (Star Twinkle PreCure): An alien from the planet Samaan.
  • Little Twelvetoes (Schoolhouse Rock): A jovial alien with green skin and six fingers and toes.
  • Marvin the Martian (Looney Tunes): A Martian often accompanied by his dog K-9.
  • Ozmodiar (The Simpsons): A parody of The Great Gazoo, only visible to Homer Simpson.
  • Roger (American Dad!): An alien living in Stan’s attic.
  • Sailor Starlights (Sailor Moon): Sailor Guardians from Planet Kinmoku.
  • Shadow Galactica (Sailor Moon): Antagonists from various planets in the Milky Way.
  • Son Goku (Dragon Ball): A Saiyan from Planet Vegeta.
  • Cure Cosmo/Yuni (Star Twinkle PreCure): A shapeshifting catgirl from Planet Rainbow.
  • Zim (Invader Zim): An Irken invader sent to conquer Earth.
  • Upgrade (Ben 10): A Galvanic Mechamorph from Galvan B.
  • Atomix (Ben 10): An alien from an unknown planet who can create nuclear energy.

Comics ðŸ”—

This section details humanoid aliens from comic books. Notable entries include:

  • Annihilus (Fantastic Four): A villain from the Marvel Universe. Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.
  • Cosmo (Cosmo the Merry Martian): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Bob White.
  • Darna (Darna): An extraterrestrial warrior who manifests in a human girl. Created by Mars Ravelo and Nestor Redondo.
  • KhÃ¢ny (Yoko Tsuno): An alien from the planet Vinea. Created by Roger Leloup.
  • Plunk (Plunk): An alien from the planet Smurk. Created by Luc Cromheecke and Laurent Letzer.
  • The Scrameustache (Scrameustache): An alien with a cat-like face. Created by Roland Goossens (Gos).
  • Mr. Skygack (Mr. Skygack, from Mars): A Martian studying human behavior. Created by A.D. Condo.
  • Superman/Clark Kent (Action Comics #1): An alien from Krypton with superhuman powers. Created by Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster.
  • Xal-Kor (Xal-Kor the Human Cat): An alien from Felis who can transform between cat, hybrid, and human forms. Created by Grass Green.
  • Zook (Zook): A Martian who visits Earth. Created by Jack Miller and Joe Certa.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in movies. Key examples include:

  • E.T. (E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial): An alien who befriends a human boy.
  • Various (Marvel Cinematic Universe): Includes Asgardians, members of the Guardians of the Galaxy, and Eternals.
  • Klaatu (The Day the Earth Stood Still): An alien who delivers a peaceful message to Earth.
  • Various (Star Wars): Includes Chewbacca, Yoda, Darth Maul, and Ahsoka Tano.
  • Zaphod Beeblebrox (The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy): An alien from near Betelgeuse.
  • Mork (Mork and Mindy): An alien from Ork who studies humanity on Earth.
  • The Alien Girl (Super Deluxe): An alien living on Earth, mingling with humans.

Literature ðŸ”—

This section compiles humanoid aliens from literary works. Notable characters include:

  • The Little Prince (The Little Prince): A prince from an asteroid who visits Earth.
  • Curtis (One Door Away from Heaven): A shape-shifting alien on the run.
  • Ras Thavas (The Master Mind of Mars): A Martian mad scientist.
  • The Thing (Who Goes There?): A shapeshifting alien that takes a human form.

Television ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens featured in television shows. Key characters include:

  • Adric (Doctor Who): A young native of Alzarius in E-Space.
  • ALF/Gordon Shumway (ALF): An alien from Melmac who crash lands on Earth.
  • Beldar, Prymaat, and Connie (Coneheads): An alien family from Remulak with conical heads.
  • Big Giant Head (3rd Rock from the Sun): The alien leader of the Solomons.
  • The Doctor (Doctor Who): An adventurer and scientist.
  • FofÃ£o (BalÃ£o MÃ¡gico and TV FofÃ£o): An extraterrestrial child character.
  • Gonzo (The Muppet Show): A puppet revealed to be of extraterrestrial origin.
  • Mork (Mork & Mindy): An alien from Ork who befriends a human woman.
  • Martin O’Hara (My Favorite Martian): A Martian anthropologist stranded on Earth.
  • Dick Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Harry Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Sally Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Tommy Solomon (3rd Rock from the Sun): An alien in human guise on Earth.
  • Spock (Star Trek): A Vulcan science officer on the Enterprise.
  • Ultraman (Ultraman): A race of aliens who protect the universe.
  • Ultronians (My Hero): A species from the planet Ultron with superpowers.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists humanoid aliens appearing in video games. Key examples include:

  • Abe (Oddworld): The central character of the Oddworld series.
  • Artanis (StarCraft): A Protoss commander and protagonist.
  • Forerunner (Halo): Ancient Humanoid Aliens that created the Halo rings.

item.title: Nazi UFOs
item.description:
Conspiracy theories alleging connections between UFOs and Nazi Germany ðŸ”—

This article explores the conspiracy theories linking UFOs to Nazi Germany, asserting that the Nazis attempted to develop advanced aircraft and spacecraft before and during World War II. It further claims that these craft survived in secret underground bases in Antarctica, South America, or the United States, along with their creators.

Early UFOs as possible Nazi technology ðŸ”—

This section discusses how unusual aerial sightings during and after World War II were initially attributed to novel Nazi technology. During the Cold War, speculation arose that the Soviets might be deploying captured or reverse-engineered Nazi technology.

Foo fighters ðŸ”—

During World War II, Allied and Axis personnel witnessed unusual aerial phenomena called “foo fighters.” While some reports were dismissed as misperceptions, others were taken seriously, leading scientists like Luis Alvarez to investigate. Allied intelligence suspected some foo fighters were advanced German aircraft or weapons, given Germany’s technological innovations like V-1 and V-2 missiles and the Me 262 jet fighter.

Ghost rockets ðŸ”—

In 1946, rocket- or missile-shaped UFOs, known as “ghost rockets,” were sighted primarily in Sweden and nearby countries. Finnish observers made the first reports in February 1946. Investigations suggested some sightings were meteors, but others displayed characteristics inconsistent with meteors, such as maneuverability. It was initially believed that the ghost rockets originated from the former German rocket facility at PeenemÃ¼nde and were Soviet tests of captured German missiles.

Flying discs ðŸ”—

Following Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting of crescent-shaped objects, speculation about German technology resurfaced. Project Sign personnel noted similarities between the Horten brothers’ flying wing designs and some UFO reports. Edward J. Ruppelt, the first head of Project Blue Book, noted that the Germans had several radical aircraft and guided missiles under development at the end of WWII.

The earliest media assertion of German flying saucers appeared in the Italian newspaper Il Giornale d’Italia in 1950. Professor Giuseppe Belluzzo claimed that flying discs were designed and studied in Germany and Italy as early as 1942.

In the same month, German technician Rudolf Schriever claimed to Der Spiegel that he designed a craft powered by rotating turbine blades while working at BMW’s Prague works until April 1945. He said his designs were stolen, and he believed Czech agents built his craft for a foreign power.

In 1953, German engineer Georg Klein claimed that designs similar to Avro Canada’s Avrocar had been developed during the Nazi era. Klein identified two types of supposed German flying disks: one developed by Richard Miethe in Breslau and another developed by Rudolf Schriever and Klaus Habermohl in Prague.

Aeronautical engineer Roy Fedden stated in 1945 that the only craft that could approach the capabilities attributed to flying saucers were those being designed by the Germans towards the end of the war.

Nazi UFO conspiracy theories ðŸ”—

By the 1960s, fringe authors began circulating tales of Nazi UFOs tied to the occult or aliens. These theories reference various potential code-names or sub-classifications of Nazi UFO craft.

German UFO literature often aligns with documented history regarding Nazi Germany’s claim to New Swabia in Antarctica and its research into advanced propulsion technology.

The Morning of the Magicians ðŸ”—

Le Matin des Magiciens, a 1960 book by Louis Pauwels and Jacques Bergier, made claims about the Vril Society of Berlin. Later writers, including Jan van Helsing, Norbert-JÃ¼rgen Ratthofer, and Vladimir Terziski, connected the Vril Society with UFOs, claiming the society contacted an alien race and developed spacecraft to reach them. They allege that the Vril Society, in partnership with the Thule Society and the Nazi Party, developed flying disc prototypes and retreated to a base in Antarctica after the Nazi defeat.

The works of Ernst ZÃ¼ndel ðŸ”—

Ernst ZÃ¼ndel’s Samisdat Publishers claimed that flying saucers were Nazi secret weapons launched from an underground base in Antarctica, aiming to conquer Earth and other planets. ZÃ¼ndel also sold seats on an exploration team to locate the polar entrance to the hollow earth.

Miguel Serrano’s book ðŸ”—

In 1978, Miguel Serrano published El CordÃ³n Dorado: Hitlerismo EsotÃ©rico, claiming that Adolf Hitler was an Avatar of Vishnu communing with Hyperborean gods in an underground Antarctic base in New Swabia. Serrano predicted that Hitler would lead a fleet of UFOs from the base to establish the Fourth Reich.

Die Glocke ðŸ”—

Die Glocke (“The Bell”) was a purported top-secret Nazi scientific technological device or Wunderwaffe. First described by Igor Witkowski in Prawda o Wunderwaffe (2000) and popularized by Nick Cook, it was associated with Nazi occultism, antigravity, and free energy suppression research. Claims about Die Glocke have been criticized as fictional and a hoax.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section lists examples of Nazi UFOs appearing in popular culture, including:

  • Robert A. Heinlein’s Rocket Ship Galileo (1947) featuring a Nazi Moon base.
  • The video game Medal of Honor: Frontline (2002) featuring a Nazi UFO.
  • The movie Iron Sky (2012) featuring a Nazi base on the moon launching an assault on Earth with flying saucers.
  • Revell releasing a scale model kit of a Nazi flying saucer called “Haunebu II” (2018), which was later removed from production due to historical inaccuracies.
  • The video game Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus (2017) featuring “Haunebu-V” craft manufactured in Nazi-controlled Roswell, New Mexico.
  • The Commando Comic Flight of Fancy (2017) featuring the Schriever Flugkreisel.
  • The second season finale of 30 Coins (2023) mentioning Haunebu UFOs as copies of Nazca UFOs.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_UFOs

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins ðŸ”—

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations ðŸ”—

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration ðŸ”—

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans ðŸ”—

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility ðŸ”—

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including interplanetary contamination, potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact, space colonization, UFO religion, The Kraken Wakes, list of films featuring space stations, and the Wow! signal.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the references used in the article, providing sources for the information presented.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_invasion

item.title: UFO (disambiguation)
item.description:
UFO (disambiguation) ðŸ”—

This page serves as a disambiguation for the term “UFO,” which primarily refers to an unidentified flying object, an aerial phenomenon that cannot be immediately identified or explained. However, “UFO” is also used in various other contexts.

Computer Technology ðŸ”—

This section lists various uses of “UFO” in the realm of computer technology. It includes:

  • .ufo: The file extension for Ulead PhotoImpact documents.
  • Unified File and Object (UFO): An object storage architecture.
  • UHF Follow-On satellite: A series of US military communications satellites.
  • Unified Font Object: An XML-based open format for digital fonts.
  • Unified Foundational Ontology: An upper ontology for conceptual modeling.

Art, Entertainment and Media ðŸ”—

This section covers the diverse applications of “UFO” in art, entertainment, and media, broken down into film and television, music, and video games.

Film and Television ðŸ”—

This subsection lists several films and television series with “UFO” in their titles:

  • UFO (1956 film): Directed by Winston Jones.
  • U.F.O. (1993 film): Starring Roy “Chubby” Brown.
  • U.F.O. (2012 film): Featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme.
  • UFO (2018 film): Directed by Ryan Eslinger, starring Alex Sharp and Gillian Anderson, focusing on an airport sighting.
  • UFO (2022 film): A Turkish Netflix film.
  • UFO (American TV series): A 2021 television documentary by J.J. Abrams.
  • UFO (British TV series): A 1970s TV series by Gerry Anderson.
  • UFOs (TV series): A 2021 French TV series.
  • UFO Ultramaiden Valkyrie: A 2000s manga and anime television series.

Music ðŸ”—

This subsection is further divided into bands and performers, albums, and songs.

Bands and Performers ðŸ”—

This section lists musical artists and groups using “UFO” in their names:

  • UFO (musician): A Danish hip hop artist, rapper, and singer (born 1981).
  • Ufo361: A German rapper (born 1988).
  • UFO (band): An English hard rock band.
  • UFO: The original name of the English R&B group better known as JLS.
  • UFO Yepha: A Danish hip hop duo.
  • The Unidentified Flying Objects: An American rock band.
  • United Future Organization: A Japanese jazz duo.

Albums ðŸ”—

This section lists albums titled “UFO”:

  • U.F.O. (album): A 1969 album by Jim Sullivan.
  • UFO EP: By Torch.
  • UFO (Newton Faulkner EP): By Newton Faulkner.

Songs ðŸ”—

This section lists songs titled “UFO”:

  • “UFO” (Mallrat song featuring Allday): (2018)
  • “UFO” (Pink Lady song): (1977)
  • “UFO”: A song by ESG on their EP ESG (1981).
  • “UFO” (Sneaky Sound System song): (2007)
  • “U.F.O.” (Coldplay song): (2011)
  • “UFO” (Vigiland song): (2014)
  • “U.F.O.”: A song by Blonde Redhead on their album La Mia Vita Violenta (1995).
  • “UFO”: A song by D-Block Europe and Aitch from the album The Blue Print: Us vs. Them (2020).

Other Musical Works ðŸ”—

  • UFO (Michael Daugherty composition): A musical composition.
  • UFOetry: A multimedia UFO rock opera.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists video games with “UFO” in their titles, including the UFO Defense family of games and other unrelated titles.

UFO Defense Family ðŸ”—

  • UFO: Enemy Unknown (1994): Also known as X-COM: UFO Defense.
  • UFO: Aftermath (2003)
  • UFO: Aftershock (2005)
  • UFO: Afterlight (2007)
  • UFO: Alien Invasion (2003)

Other Video Games ðŸ”—

  • UFO (1989): By Sublogic.
  • UFO Kamen Yakisoban (1994): For Super Famicom.
  • U.F.O.s (1997): An adventure game by Artech.
  • UFO: A Day in the Life (1999): By Love-de-Lic.
  • UFO: Extraterrestrials (2007): By Chaos Concept.
  • Undefined Fantastic Object (2009): The twelfth entry in the Touhou Project series by ZUN.

Other Works ðŸ”—

  • UFOs: The Greatest Stories: A 1996 short-story anthology by Martin H. Greenberg.

Games and Sports ðŸ”—

  • Claw vending machine: Also known as UFO.
  • UFO: A style of delivery in Ten-pin bowling.

Clubs ðŸ”—

This section lists clubs with “UFO” in their names:

  • Ufo (Club, Berlin): An Acid House club.
  • UFO Club: A London underground club.

Products and Services ðŸ”—

This section lists products and services branded with “UFO”:

  • UFO: A brand of instant yakisoba.
  • UFO (restaurant): A restaurant in Slovakia.
  • UFO (ride): An amusement park ride.

Other Uses ðŸ”—

This section lists other miscellaneous uses of the acronym “UFO”:

  • United Farmers of Ontario: A Canadian political party c. 1920s.
  • UFO: A variant of float b-boy move.
  • Ufo (wasp): A genus of wasps.
  • UFO 34 (yacht): A sailboat.
  • UFO Radio: A radio station in Taiwan.
  • Uranium Fluorine Oxygen: Representing the chemical elements.
  • Ultra Fast Outflows: Winds that come from supermassive black holes.
  • University of French Ontario: Referring to the UniversitÃ© de l’Ontario franÃ§ais.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related disambiguation pages and topics:

  • U-Foes: A Marvel Comics supervillain team.
  • Unidentified flying object (disambiguation)
  • Flying saucer (disambiguation)
  • Alien (disambiguation)
