item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of Alien Races in DC Comics ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article provides a comprehensive list of fictional extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics publications and related media. It includes brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section lists the alphabetical index of alien races covered in the article, from 0-9 to Z, along with links to “See also,” “References,” and “External links” sections.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the concept of the vast number of extraterrestrial races in the DC Comics universe, noting that the majority are humanoid in structure.

United Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the United Planets, a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. It mentions known members like planets of the Solar System, Htrae, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. It also notes that in the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros. The section is marked as needing expansion.

0-9 ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with numbers.

5th Dimensional Imps ðŸ”—

This section details the 5th Dimensional Imps from the planet Zrfff, including notable characters like Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Bat-Mite, and Zook. It also mentions their appearances in other media, such as the Supergirl TV series, where Mxyzptlk and Nyxlygsptlnz appear, and a Supergirl crossover with The Flash, where the Music Meister is revealed to be an imp.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

Adaptoids ðŸ”—

This section describes the Adaptoids, blob-like creatures from the vicinity of Arcturus who attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans ðŸ”—

This section details the Aellans, yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello, Demonia, and Harpis. Harpis and Doc of Aello were members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Alien Invaders as the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci ðŸ”—

This section describes the Almeraci, a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities, ruled by the matriarchal House of the Blood Royale. Key figures include Maxima, Queen of Almerac, her handmaiden Sazu, and Ultraa.

Aloi ðŸ”—

This section details the Aloi, blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device called the “Grayl.” Tumlat represents them.

Alstairans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Alstairans of Alstair, plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, constantly at war with other races in the Antares system. Their ruler is Hyathis, an alien plant elemental.

Anasazi ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Anasazi as metahumans resettled to the planet Starhaven, represented by Dawnstar.

Andromedans ðŸ”—

This section details the Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy, a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites, with red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak, an Andromedan exiled to Earth, is mentioned.

Angtuans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Angtuans, inhabitants of the planet Angtu, which was destroyed by the mutated Mano in the 30th century.

Anunnake ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Anunnake as reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs, also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann ðŸ”—

This section details the Anndrann, green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a negative effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Appellaxians of Appellax, technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. Their invasion led to the formation of the Justice League. The section also mentions their appearance in Young Justice, where Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem.

Aipitons ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Aipitons as small flying insects from the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Aquoids as natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes ðŸ”—

This section details the Aranes of Arane II, light blue-skinned humanoids with tiny blue horns. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Ardenans as orange scaly-skinned humanoids from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Astonians, a minor alien race saved from extinction by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker, who is of this race.

Azarathians ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Azarathians as people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

Barrions ðŸ”—

This section details the Barrions of Barrio III, silicon-based lifeforms represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Bellatrix Bombers as alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bgztlians, humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes represents them.

Blight ðŸ”—

This section details the Blight, a cybernetic race with rotting flesh, villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos, who sought immortality from M’onel.

Bloodline Parasites ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bloodline Parasites, extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of activating the human metagene while feeding on spinal fluid. They have exoskeletons, strength, and the ability to duplicate human form.

Braalians ðŸ”—

This section details the Braalians, humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes represent them.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X ðŸ”—

This section describes the Brain-Parasites of Planet X, who steal knowledge from other races using Knowledge-Extractors.

Branx ðŸ”—

This section details the Branx of Emana Branx, gray-skinned, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians. They are native to the Vega star system.

Brylyx ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Brylyx as white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bolovax Vikians, a highly communal and technologically advanced race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member. The section also mentions a holographic Bolovax Vikian appearing in My Adventures with Superman.

Bugs of New Genesis ðŸ”—

This section details the Bugs of New Genesis, an insectoid race spread on New Genesis during their war with Apokolips. Forager and Mantis are prominent members.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

Cairnians ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Cairnians as members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Calatonians, an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by Doomsday.

Canopians ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Canopians as members of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites ðŸ”—

This section describes the Carggites, humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes represents them.

Catherix ðŸ”—

This section details the Cathexis, alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality-endangering technology.

Changralynians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Changralynians of Changralyn, silicon-based pacifists represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Chietain ðŸ”—

This section is marked as needing expansion.

Children of Tanjent ðŸ”—

This section identifies the Children of Tanjent as a psionic race.

Circadians ðŸ”—

This section describes the peaceful insectoid Circadians of Circadia, who established a joint human/Circadian settlement known as Pax Colony. Circadia Senius is a Chronarch Research Fellow and friend of Brainiac 5.

Chthalonians ðŸ”—

This section is marked as needing expansion.

Citadelians ðŸ”—

This section details the Citadelians of the Citadel, sadistic imperialistic clones whose intellect degrades with each generation. They use Gordanians and Branx Warriors as enforcers.

Clementians ðŸ”—

This

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parademon

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Purported disk-shaped aircraft ðŸ”—

This article discusses the history, description, and cultural impact of “flying saucers,” a term popularized in the late 1940s to describe disc-shaped unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It distinguishes flying saucers from the broader category of UFOs/UAPs and explores their evolution in popular culture.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and development of the flying saucer phenomenon.

Precursors ðŸ”—

This subsection explores earlier reports of unusual aerial phenomena that predate the term “flying saucer.” These include:

  • Mysterious lights in the sky interpreted as spiritual phenomena in antiquity.
  • 19th-century newspaper reports of massive airships.
  • The 1878 Denison Daily News article describing an object resembling a saucer.
  • “Foo fighters” reported by Allied pilots during World War II.
  • Science fiction stories featuring disc-shaped aircraft, such as Jean de La Hire’s 1908 novel La Roue fulgurante and “The Shaver Mystery” stories in Amazing Stories magazine.
  • Fantasy artwork in pulp magazines depicting flying discs.

Origins ðŸ”—

This subsection details the event that is credited with popularizing the term “flying saucer”:

  • The Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting on June 24, 1947, in Washington State.
  • Arnold’s description of the objects’ motion as “like a saucer skipping across the water.”
  • The media’s coining of the terms “flying saucer” and “flying disc.”
  • The subsequent wave of reported sightings across the United States, including the Flight 105 UFO sighting and the Roswell incident.
  • Early speculation about the objects’ origins, including secret military technology and Soviet aircraft.

Development ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the evolution of the flying saucer concept and its association with extraterrestrial life:

  • The increasing association of flying saucers with extraterrestrial life in the 1950s.
  • Kenneth Arnold’s speculation about an extraterrestrial origin for the objects.
  • The emergence of unusual theories, such as Meade Layne’s speculation about alternate dimensions.
  • The influence of pulp science fiction on beliefs about flying saucers.
  • The rise of the “contactee” movement, with individuals like George Van Tassel and George Adamski claiming to have ridden aboard saucers and received messages from aliens.
  • The development of ufology as a parallel social movement, with figures like Frank Scully, Donald Keyhoe, and Leonard H. Stringfield publishing books and forming UFO investigation groups.
  • The emergence of UFO photography as a subgenre of documentary photography.
  • The eventual decline in popularity of the term “flying saucer” and its replacement by “UFO” and “UAP.”

Description ðŸ”—

This section describes the characteristics and identification of flying saucers.

Identification ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the identification of reported flying saucers with known phenomena:

  • Experts have identified the majority of UFO reports as misidentifications or hoaxes.
  • Common explanations for saucer sightings include the planet Venus, weather phenomena, balloons, and airborne trash.
  • The US Navy’s Skyhook spy balloon project, which led to numerous misidentified sightings.
  • Psychological studies of why people believe in flying saucers, including Georges Heuyer’s view of the phenomenon as a shared delusion and Michel Monnerie’s psychosocial UFO hypothesis.

Reported sightings ðŸ”—

This subsection summarizes the characteristics of reported flying saucer sightings:

  • Eyewitness descriptions differ in reported appearance, movement, and purpose.
  • Astronomer Donald Howard Menzel’s overview of flying saucers, noting the variety of shapes, sizes, colors, and movements reported.
  • The increasing standardization of alien descriptions over time, with Grey aliens becoming the most reported type of pilot.
  • The influence of popular social and cultural expectations on the details of claimed observations.

Fictional portrayals ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in popular media:

  • Early portrayals emphasized high-speed maneuvers, while later media shifted to slowly hovering discs.
  • Examples of films and television series that feature flying saucers, such as The Flying Saucer, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and The Invaders.

Popular culture ðŸ”—

This section explores the cultural impact of flying saucers.

Literature ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the appearance of flying saucers in literature:

  • Precursors to modern flying saucers appeared in science fiction literature, including The Shaver Mystery.
  • The emergence of a genre that treated fantastical stories as either true or plausibly true.
  • The use of advertisements to leverage cultural interest in flying saucers.
  • The appearance of aliens and flying discs in 1950s science fiction comics.

Film and television ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the portrayal of flying saucers in film and television:

  • Many early portrayals of flying saucers linked them to the Cold War.
  • Examples of films that feature flying saucers, such as The Thing from Another World, The Day the Earth Stood Still, and Earth vs. the Flying Saucers.
  • The adaptation of the flying saucer phenomenon by other countries, such as Japan and India.
  • The use of flying saucers in other genres, such as science fiction and comedy.

Architecture ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the use of flying saucer motifs in architecture:

  • The flying saucer as a symbol of 1950s culture.
  • The use of flying saucer motifs in Googie architecture and Atomic Age dÃ©cor.
  • Notable flying saucer structures, such as Seattle’s Space Needle and Los Angeles International Airport’s Theme Building.
  • The influence of Googie architecture on the futuristic structures in the cartoon The Jetsons.
  • The use of the flying saucer as an architectural motif by Frank Lloyd Wright.
  • Examples of novelty architecture shaped like flying saucers, such as the Kielce Bus Station in Poland and the Spodek arena in Katowice, Poland.

Broader pop culture ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the broader cultural impact of flying saucers:

  • Flying saucers were a ubiquitous part of pop culture from 1947 into the mid-1970s.
  • The use of flying disc motifs in toys and other novelties, such as the frisbee and flying saucer candy.
  • The release of novelty songs about flying discs and alien invaders.
  • The appearance of flying saucers in video games, typically as antagonists.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_saucers

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis ðŸ”—

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term ðŸ”—

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature. It notes that the term gained traction in the latter half of the 1960s, with early usage attributed to French ufologist Jacques VallÃ©e in his 1966 book. Other figures who used the term in the late 1960s include AimÃ© Michel, James E. McDonald, and James Harder. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report. Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical context leading up to the modern ETH. It traces the origins of the idea of extraterrestrial life and visitation to earlier concepts, including Percival Lowell’s theories about Martian canals and ancient Martian civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH, linking unidentified aircraft to alien life, took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits ðŸ”—

This section presents examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a French newspaper story from 1864 about the discovery of an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian visitation and invasion. The section notes a surge in “mystery airship” reports in the late 19th century, with some speculating about Martian origins. It also mentions the influence of comic strips, radio shows, and movies like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon in popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused some public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion ðŸ”—

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies ðŸ”—

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH ðŸ”—

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery ðŸ”—

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists ðŸ”—

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology ðŸ”—

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA ðŸ”—

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

Official White ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_hypothesis

item.title: Lists of fictional extraterrestrials
item.description:
Lists of Fictional Extraterrestrial Species ðŸ”—

This page serves as a central index for various lists cataloging fictional extraterrestrial species found across different media. It also provides links to related topics like fictional species in general.

Alphabetical ðŸ”—

This section provides a comprehensive alphabetical listing of links to individual pages, each dedicated to fictional alien species whose names begin with a specific letter of the alphabet. This allows users to quickly navigate to species based on their name. For example, there are links for A, B, C, and so on, up to Z.

By Medium & Franchise ðŸ”—

This section organizes lists of fictional extraterrestrial species based on the specific medium or franchise in which they appear.

Literature ðŸ”—

  • List of Noon Universe alien races: Links to the section on alien races within the Noon Universe, a science fiction setting created by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky.

Comics ðŸ”—

  • List of alien races in DC Comics: Directs to a list of alien species featured in publications by DC Comics.
  • List of alien races in Marvel Comics: Directs to a list of alien species featured in publications by Marvel Comics.

Film and Television ðŸ”—

  • List of Doctor Who universe creatures and aliens: Links to a comprehensive list of creatures and aliens appearing in the Doctor Who franchise.
  • List of Star Trek aliens: Links to a list of alien species from the Star Trek universe.
  • List of Star Wars creatures: Links to a list of creatures from the Star Wars universe.
  • Lists of Star Wars species: Provides a breakdown of Star Wars species lists, divided alphabetically:
    • Aâ€“E
    • Fâ€“J
    • Kâ€“O
    • Pâ€“T
    • Uâ€“Z
  • Species of the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Links to a list of species appearing in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Games ðŸ”—

  • Battlelords of the 23rd Century#Races: Links to the section detailing alien races in the Battlelords of the 23rd Century role-playing game.
  • Races of Mass Effect: Links to a list of the various alien races featured in the Mass Effect video game series.
  • Races of StarCraft: Links to a list of the various alien races featured in the StarCraft video game series.

By Appearance ðŸ”—

This section categorizes alien species based on their physical characteristics.

  • List of humanoid aliens: Links to a list of alien species that resemble humans in their basic body plan.
  • List of reptilian humanoids: Links to a list of humanoid aliens that possess reptilian features.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to other relevant lists and templates related to fictional life forms and science fiction in general. It includes a comprehensive table linking to lists of fictional plants, animals (categorized by type), humanoids, and other creatures, as well as templates for fictional biology and science fiction topics.

item.title: UFO (video game)
item.description:
UFO (video game) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1989 video game UFO, published by Sublogic for MS-DOS.

Gameplay ðŸ”—

This section explains the core gameplay of UFO. The player controls an alien flying saucer with the objective of harvesting energy from humans by inducing fear.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception of the game. Daniel Hockman of Computer Gaming World reviewed the game, noting its uniqueness and challenging flight demands. He suggested that players looking for something different and willing to overlook the polygon graphics might enjoy it.

Reviews ðŸ”—

This section lists reviews of the game that appeared in various publications:

  • ASM (Aktueller Software Markt) - Nov, 1989
  • The Games Machine - Jan, 1990
  • Computer Gaming World - Nov, 1992

References ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of references used in the article:

  1. James Hague’s “The Giant List of Classic Game Programmers”
  2. Daniel Hockman’s review in Computer Gaming World (December 1989)
  3. Review in The Games Machine Issue 26

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_(video_game)
